He stated it, he didn't state whether it was in vial or how it was.
I assumed it was in the vial because that at least was the way it went to the chemist.
Was the time they saw that after they made this motion?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: First they --
After they made motion on page 2, was that when they saw the physical --?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: As I read the record Your Honor, first they were allowed to view the evidence personally.
Then they made the motion --
When?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: They made the motion to view the evidence as I read it prior to the motion to make the scientific examination of the evidence.
And were allowed to look at it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: They were, Your Honor.
And then they made the motion for the (Voice Overlap).

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
And that was the one that was denied?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Was the original motion granted is that it for defense?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I am not aware, Your Honor, whether it was just granted by the prosecution or whether there was a court order on that.
Did the Court make -- state any reason as to why it was denying him a right to examine?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: The Court does not.
The -- in the Court the state's attorney was asked why he opposed that motion, and he testified Your Honor that he opposed it because they -- he could not be assured.
He was not assured that the evidence would not be -- the chain of evidence would not be some way destroyed by the tests that were going to be taken.
That is why he opposed it, the reason -- the ruling of the judge, however, is not in the record.
The reason or the ruling of the judge is not in the record, Your Honor.
We turn then Your Honors to the question of the bloody shorts.
Now, the chemist for the state literally testified at the trial -- testified at the trial that the shorts did contain blood.
And the state's attorney also testified -- stated in argument referred to these shorts as bloody shorts.
Now, at the District Court in the habeas corpus proceeding --
May I ask before you get to the District Court.
If the prosecuting attorney describe the blood that was on them or the amount of it, or did he make any representation as to whether this is blood on the shorts?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: I do not think the record indicated that he pointed to any spot, Your Honor.
It said this is blood.
He referred to the document in general as the bloody shorts.
Well, there are more than spots on that.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
It's covered with something which they now say is paint.
And I wonder if was that represented to the jury in any way as being the blood stained shorts without distinguishing --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: No statement was made to the jury Your Honor, as far as I know that there was any paint on these.
There was then therefore, the jury would, I assume allow to draw the inference that all the spots were those of blood.
On the other hand, I do not think any direct statement was made any given spot or all spots were blood.
When did the question first come up about the paint?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: As far as I know Your Honor, in the District Court they did make a scientific examination of all the evidence.
One Martin, a chemist employed by the petitioner here, took 12 strands at out of the more heavily stained areas of that garment, 12 fibers.
He examined those 12 fibers, each out of one of the heavily stained areas.
His testimony was that ten of the fibers contained paint.
One of the fibers are kind of a carbon substance and one of the fibers an unidentified substance.
Mr. Michael, when the shorts were introduced at the trial, did the defense make a motion at that time that they be permitted to have a scientific examination of it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: As far as I know Your Honor, and I think this is correct, the only motion from the scientific examination was the one that we have referred to with respect to --
Alright, now try to get at the theory of this case.
Suppose at the trial, the state offers the shorts and testimony is to be offered or is being or has been offered to the effect that those are blood stains.
The defense then moves in an appropriate way to be given the opportunity to have a scientific examination of the shorts.
In Illinois law, what would happen?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Generally speaking, I would submit that it would be granted, Your Honor.

The general rule under Illinois law is that, it was enunciated by the Court by the way in reviewing this case, is that there is a qualified -- red-light lining to the discretion of the Court to allow the defense to make scientific evidence of the --
I suppose the trial judge said in all this, No, I won't let you do that.
Would that be an error under Illinois law?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If there were no further basis than that Your Honor, I submit that yes it would be.
I thought you said there was discretion on it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It could be reviewed however for abuse of discretion.
You think it would be introduced as discretion?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I would if there were no reason at all for denying a motion to make scientific evidence, I would submit that it would be in abuse of discretion.
Why, because it's a denial of fair trial?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, sir.
Well why, that's constitutional principle too, isn't it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: To the extent that Brady versus Maryland so enunciates it, yes sir.
Did -- may I ask this, did the report of the state's experts who examined these shorts report that the major portion of what's on there is paint?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: The report of the state's expert on that Your Honor was that he had examined it, he had found paint and he made no -- I take it back, he had found blood and he made no test for any other substance.
And he made no reference in his report that the -- that what is so observable there is paint and not blood?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: The chemist did not, Your Honor.
The state's attorney in the District Court did testify that he knew that all of the stains on it were not blood.
That is all we have in the record on that issue.
He knew that at the time that the shorts was introduced in evidence?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He so testified in the District Court, Your Honor.
But he didn't disclose that time?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He did not, Your Honor.
You know whether in summation he used the garment in his summation to the jury?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He certainly referred to the bloody shots.
Of course, the report of the short hand report, it would not indicate whether he was waiving it or --
But at the time he made reference to it.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He did, Your Honor.
He knew that there was -- that at least all of the spots were not blood but some or something else.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
And said nothing about it.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Where does that -- I want to be sure he's sure what he did admit it to his knowledge at the time of -- at the clemency hearing or at the habeas corpus hearing --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: At the habeas corpus --
-- he admitted as to his knowledge at the time of the trial that some of the stains, that at least some of the stains were not blood.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Volume 2, Your Honor, page 581.
Volume 2, page 581.
Well, this -- is this the prosecuting attorney at the trial who's testifying?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, I beg to change that to make it 580, Your Honor.
This is Blaine Ramsey?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This is Blaine Ramsey, yes Your Honor, at the bottom of the page.
Let me ask you this Mr. Ramsey.
As a matter of fact Mr. Ramsey didn't you know at the time of the trial Lloyd Eldon Miller Jr., that these spots in this examination were not blood?
Oh!
I knew that all of them were not blood, yes sir.
That's what you were referring to the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, I was.
Thank you.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then he said also, With regard to those that can be seen by the naked eye, you knew at the time of trial, didn't you, that those spots that could be seen by the naked eye were not blood spots.
You knew that, didn't you?
Well not conclusively.
I had knowledge from a chemist that there was blood on it.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes sir.
I see that's his further testimony.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Michaels, who was Mr. Litterly?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He was a chemist, Your Honor, employed by the state bureau of -- I don't really -- criminal -- the scientific arm of the state government at that time.
What about the statement on his testimony at 581.
Now as to those spots which you knew were not blood, what did you know those to be?
What did you know of those Mr. Ramsey?
I'm trying to recollect that.
They said there was also paint on that I think that is remembered only.
Who said it was paint?
I presume Mr. Litterly but I really do not recall.

Is that -- are we to get -- take from this that he's suggesting that at the time it was offered at trial, he knew more of then that there were some spots were not blood, he knew that there were spots that were paint, is that it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He testified there Your Honor that he knew that some of those spots were paint, I would assume.
But Litterly testified at the trial that he didn't make test on the non-blood.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Right, Your Honor.
He testified only that he had examined for blood and he had made no other tests on the garment.
But in order to -- he tested for blood but he didn't find blood in some of those spots.
At least that is a fair reading of his testimony.
He knew that some of the stains were not blood, so he did test the stains for blood.
And if the prosecuting attorney knew at the time that some of the stains were not blood, the only source of information could be from Mr. Litterly, I presume.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, I would assume that that would be correct.
And his source of information would I assume be a written report?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The written report from Litterly is in the record, and at my recollection of it, it is in the echo -- the report of the exhibits.
The report of Litterly is found at --
This is not the trial, isn't it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No this is the exhibits from the habeas corpus proceeding, Your Honor.
Habeas corpus.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I think it's number six, Your Honor I'm looking at it now to verify it.
Yes, it is petitioner's exhibit number six.
This is what the prosecuting attorney knew?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Where -- which one of these items applies to the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The reproduction is not very good.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, it isn't Your Honor.
I'm trying to Your Honor, I'm -- do you have one of your first?
Yes, that's much better.
I see some --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's -- at the next to last page, Your Honor.
Can you read it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes I can from the original or much better copy of the report than you have available.
The pair of white jockey shorts?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Described as number 17?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Were examined by chemical means and found to be heavily stained with blood.
Further serological examination include the blood was of human origin.
It was probably of group A.
Numerous hairs and fibers were herein to the shorts and were mounted in microscopic examination, a comparison of those hairs of pubic hairs 10 to 15 millimeters.
Some similar characteristics, no definite opinions of whether or not the common origin is possible.
One of the fibers found in the shorts was mounted and compared microscopically, samples of the fibers of the inner pant lining the color, size, etcetera.
No mention of paint at all.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No mention of paint, Your Honor.
Oh, what page is that on do you say?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: These are not numbered, Your Honor.
This is exhibit number six, the next to the last page, Your Honor.
Well, this -- there's no mention here that some of the stains were not blood.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No there is not, Your Honor.
Well, then where did the prosecuting attorney get his information that some of the stains were not blood?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I do not know, Your Honor.
All I know is that in the District Court he --
Well, how about Mr. Litterly's testimony?
He did testify that some of the stains were --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
He testified that he -- he did not testify that some of the stains were not.
He testified that he knew that some of the stains were not blood.
Well, how about the testimony at the trial?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Litterly's testimony at the trial you're referring to now, Your Honor?
Did he then say -- he didn't make any mention at all as to other stains, did he, in his testimony?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, Your Honor.
Litterly's testimony at the trial appears in the brown colored Volume 4 at page 168.
Okay, thank you very much.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It stated, I examined and tested People's Exhibit 3 to determine the nature of the staining material thereon.
That result of the first test was that this material upon the shorts is blood.
I made a second examination it's as close as the blood of human origin and made a further examination which disclosed that the blood was of group A.
That was his testimony at that time.
Well, now that -- he made more -- testify?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Pardon me?
More fully did he, on the habeas corpus?
Where was it that he finally conceded that some of the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm not sure that he ever did.
It was the state's attorney who conceded that he knew that some of the stains were not blood, Your Honor.
That's the thing I referred to in form of my question.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
Yes, Your Honor.
I see.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We submit that on this issue, Your Honors, the critical point is whether there was blood on these shorts.
The petitioner testified that he --

Well, don't you think under a case like Napue against Illinois, the critical point is, even if there was blood on those shorts, a misrepresentation that the stains you could see there was blood when they knew it was -- if they knew it was paint.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If there --
Isn't that the knowing use of concept of misrepresentation by the prosecution in a criminal case?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If there is blood on these shorts, Your Honor, and the mere testimony by the prosecution only is that there are -- is blood in these shorts.
And if they do refer to them as bloody shorts, if there is blood on them, I submit that even though there's also paint, there is no going beyond the truth, if you will, as indicated by Napue.
Well, as I understand it, today you can't find any blood on it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
On what's in there.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: However, the chemist for the prosecution did testify that he had no opinion today as to whether there was any blood on it or not.
Today the appearance of those and the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Except for one stain, Your Honor that is unidentifiable in origin.
Well, Mr. Michaels as you held those up, I don't -- it hardly seems an unspotted -- look at that.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It --
If the blood has now disappeared, there's certainly an awful lot of paint.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes there is, Your Honor.
Suppose the prosecutor had expressly represented to the jury that all of those spots were blood, would that have been your judgment, would that have been error under Illinois law?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I would think not only under Illinois but under the decision of this Court it would have been, Your Honor.
That's because it would've not been consummate with our ideas of a fair trial.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes sir.
So that what we have here is the variation in the sense that there was represented but there was blood on the shorts with no particularization of the exhibit, which was physically before the jury.
It was not all blood but mostly paint as to the appearance to the naked eye now.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes sir.
However, I do want to go back to the point I was making with respect to Mr. Justice Stewart's question.
The petitioner did testify in his confession, admitted in his confession that these were his shorts.
The critical issue --
Incidentally, where does this confession appear here, anywhere I can't --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, it is in the record, Your Honor on before -- it appears really in two places.
One, Mr. Christensen who took the confession, testified as to what he said to him during the interrogation and then another time that Mr. Baudino read his confession into the record.
Where are the two places?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Christensen's statement begins on 128, I believe it is, Your Honor.
That would be of Volume 1?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This would be the trial transcript, Your Honor, the brown covered by --
Volume 4.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Volume 4.
Sorry to take your time but I haven't --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no.
Then you have the -- we are looking now, Your Honor, for the -- where the confession.
Right, thank you very much.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was there any evidence in the record of about how that paint got on those shorts?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: No, there's nothing at all, Your Honor, as far as I know.
What was this man's occupation?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Would you excuse me?
The confession Your Honor of the defendant was right under the record of page 144.
Pardon me, Your Honor?
I asked, what was his occupation?
As I recall it was evidence of him being a taxi driver.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Yes there was, Your Honor.
He was not a painter.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: No, he was not, Your Honor.
I understood there was some evidence in one of the proceedings to the effect that these shorts did not fit the defendant.
Is there anything from the prosecution to rebut that?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: The testimony was, Your Honor, that the -- they would've been tight and uncomfortable if he had worn them.
There's nothing to rebut that, Your Honor.
Was there any rebuttal of that?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, there was not, Your Honor.
Anything to show that the confirmation of the man had changed in the years that he was either fatter or thinner at the time this testimony was taken and at the time of the crime?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, there was not, Your Honor.
Perhaps I misunderstood.
I thought you were starting to tell us at the time that I interrupted you to ask you where in the record the confession appeared.
I thought you were trying to starting to tell us that in his confession, he admitted that those shorts were his?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, he did Your Honor, in his confession.
He later denied it.
But he never made any confession.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, but in his confession he admitted that the shorts were his.
And so I submit that the relevant question is whether they did contain blood.
If they did contain blood, this was the critical point.
The presence of paint in addition to the blood, I respectfully submit, was immaterial.
Where did they get the shorts, from him?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: They found -- a policeman found them in a old abandoned apartment building which was referred to at that time as the Van Buren Flats.

In his confession, he stated that he had discarded them in the Van Buren Flats, but if I remember the testimony correctly, the police had found it before his confession if I'm not mistaken on that point.
I'm sorry must have read them -- perhaps I read it too quickly.
This is the confession at page 145?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
147, can you refer me to the admission that these particular shorts were his?
I see that there is -- he states that he removed the shorts, but I don't find any --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Perhaps it was in the statement of Mr. Christensen sir.
I see.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If you don't find it there.
I don't find it in the confession.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I found -- I find on a page 130 that he said he did this -- discard his shorts at Van Buren Flats, but that doesn't -- that's not the same as saying that those shorts are his.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I agree with that, Your Honor.
My recollection from the record is that he was shown the flats and he stated that they were -- I maybe in error on that.
It was my recollection from reading the record, Your Honor.
Well he agreed that -- he conceded that they had been left at this place and they found these at that place.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
That's probably might be accountable for your error.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: That is --
I find what you're referring to now, on page 132 just below the center of the page.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Michael, I gather the impression from reading the phrase that the state in introducing the confession and the presentation of its case told the jury or left the impression with the jury that he have had obtained the confession of the defendant and then had verified it through these things and that they had found these things as a result of the confession.
And I gather the impression also that there had been evidence later produced to show that they had these things before the confession and verify them by this confession.
Now, did the state deny the latter?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: As I remember that point, Your Honor, it's my understanding that the reading of the record that the items were found before the confession.
Yes.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now --
Was that at any time represented to the jury that these things were found afterwards as a result of that confession?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: The petitioner has claimed that they are, Your Honor.
As I read that section that he referred to, I was not -- I thought it was ambiguous which way they were referring to it.
Would you have that citation recorded?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Don't you think that's -- that might be important?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: If there were knowing misrepresentation to closing argument, I would say it would be very significant, Your Honor.

If there was no evidence, however, brought out that he deliberately misstated anything, it is possible that a mistake could occur in -- by prosecution in closing argument which would not be deliberate mistake and would not amount to constitutional proportions.

But neither that an important thing, it seems to me, whether these things were found and developed as a result of the plain confession that he made or whether they had these things and before the confession and did not report it to the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: The argument that you are referring to, Your Honor, is on page 375 of the volume printed by this Court, Volume 4, Your Honor.
And it relates to the jacket of my -- attorney for the petitioner in form where he relates --
Where is that, the upper part of the volume?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: About the middle of the page I believe, Your Honor.
They could not have known, but when they put it there to find, the jacket was found where he had said he had put it.
Words are about the middle of the page, Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: I beg your -- 375, I beg your pardon.
That's the one they could not have known, but when they went there to find the jacket it was found --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes sir.
-- where he said he put it.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
We turn then Your Honors --
Now, did -- is -- which is true, that they did find this thing after the confession or before?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: My understanding of the record is that they found it before the confession, Your Honor.
And that this, while it might not have been with intention to deceive, but was, untrue?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: If that is -- as I read that, Your Honor, I am not absolutely clear just what the meaning of it.
If you interpret that as saying that we took his -- what he told us and went out and there we found it then it would be untrue, yes Your Honor.
Yes.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: We turn then to the question of the advice to Mrs. Baxter that she had a right not to talk to the defense in this case.
Now, Mrs. Baxter testified at the pardon and parole proceedings that she had been receiving many calls and was being bothered by the defense attorney and she was, in her words, perturbed.
She called up the state's attorney and asked what the situation was.
He told her in effect that, You have a right not to talk to the defense if you want to.

This is corroborated by his own testimony at the District Court where he testified that he told other witnesses amongst her that by request that they had a right not to talk to the defense and they must make up their own mind whether they wanted to or not.
Now, we submit that this statement is absolutely correct.
Absent a subpoena to some particular hearing, every private individual has a right not only to talk not to the defense, but not to talk to the prosecution, absent an appropriate subpoena.
We submit that there was absolutely no violation of any rights in respect to that statement.
I was wondering about her testimony when it was offered and when the Court was asked for permission to permit her testimony as a court witness.
The prosecution said they would consent to it only if her unreliability was conceded.
Now, why would that -- is that a normal thing?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Let me correct that statement.
Just -- my understanding, Your Honor is with that the Court said that rather than the prosecution.
The Court said, If you will state to me that she is unreliable in some way, I will allow you to call her as a court's witness.
If you do not so state then I will give you great latitude in asking leading questions and various examinations you want, but I will not call her as a court witness.
They then refused that offer -- they refused the Court's offer to have called her and have this great leeway in question -- with respect to leading questions.
I assume they testified because they did not want to be bound by the testimony of someone whom they did not know who was going to testify.
Is that a test of whether a person -- the defendant should be entitled to call a witness as the Court's witness that he must admit that there's some unreliability?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: I think it is -- the question is pretty much within the discretion of the Court, Your Honor.
And I don't think it's subject to review for abuse in the same way as the scientific evidence was as I referred earlier to the question of Mr. Justice Fortas.
I think that if the Court -- if you can show some reason to the Court why he should be called as the Court's witness, that he pretty well usually is.
The Court, in exercise of its discretion in this case, merely believed that they had not shown sufficient grounds to exercise his discretion in that regard.
We turn then to the question of the unreliable witness, Betty Baldwin, not Betty Baldwin-Curry.
The prosecution -- the petitioner in this case contends that the prosecution was in error for calling that witness when they knew that she was unreliable.

We submit, Your Honors, that there is absolutely no constitutional requirement that prohibits the calling of a witness, who in the past has not been believed if, and this is the big if, they do believe her testimony on this occasion.
Now, on this occasion, the evidence is rather complete that at least two people so testified that they fully believed her on this occasion.
On that basis, they called her and we believe that it is a proper to call a witness whose testimony you believe even though at some past occasion you may not have believed this witness' testimony.
Which one would they believe?
Which part of her testimony would they believe, for in the Court, she said she had known him for two years and prior to that time she had told the police that she knew him for five weeks?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, there is another factor in that regard, Your Honor.
When -- if the she had told the police that she knew him at the time of the crime for five weeks.
Now, this question was asked at the trial which was ten months after the crime.
How long have you known him, not how long had you known him Your Honor, not how long had you known him at the time of the crime, but how long have you known him, which means from the present past.
And I submit, Your Honor, that the correct answer to that would have been 11 months, because she had known him at the time that question was asked for 11 months.
Now, I submit Your Honor, that to allow that to go unrefuted is absolutely immaterial.
There is no materiality at all in this record to the significance of whether that she had known him 11 months or two years.
The defendant states there is some materiality --
Do you have the citation to that, but don't take the time to look.
If you don't know, don't bother.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: You mean as to the -- where as to the formal questioned asked?
As to whether they said, How long have you known him?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes I have it right here, Your Honor, it's in Volume 2, -- Volume 2 page 702 at the top of the page.
At the very top of the page, Your Honor, it refers Do you know the defendant Lloyd Eldon Miller?
She said, Yes sir.
How long have you known him?
Approximately two years.

The principle -- there is concluding that thought Your Honor also if there's a contention under Napue versus Illinois that they allowed knowing testimony to go in the record as they did not contradict that statement.
There is absolutely no evidence in this record that they were aware of the statement was made.

Now, there was the fact that that statement had been made to the prosecution, but there was no evidence that they had gone down that statement and checked every one of her answers against them, I'm sure they knew it in substance.

But this was such a, I submit, immaterial point that they probably didn't even realize that she was violating the statement that they had given, or at least there's no evidence in the record that they had, Your Honor.

Mr. Michael, may I ask you concerning this witness if it is the fact that they have concluded before this proceeding that this witness had made a false accusation against another person for a crime that she said he had confessed to her but was not true.

And then also that she had made another one which was under investigation and which the experts found that it was inconclusive but they believed that she was not telling the truth and that the county authorities who prosecuted this case suggested that they discontinue the investigation of the truth of that statement until this case was tried so she could be a witness here.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your Honor, what you say is very -- is in substance.
Now, I know of only one prior occasion that she had made a story about another crime that was this narcotics story.
With respect to that statement, she was given a lie detector test to check whether it was right.
The result was inconclusive.
They said that they found -- they did not believe her, although the test was inconclusive and that they were going to drop the matter.
The only other instance that I can think of which talks to their -- to the unreliability relates to the statement that Mr. Malmgren, the attorney for the petitioner had tried to coerce this witness.
Now, as far as I read the record in this case, those claims have never been disproving, Your Honor.

I understood that there was an investigation of that, and the authorities indicated that they thought that was not true, but the people who prosecuted this case suggested that the investigation be discontinued until after the trial of this case.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: That was -- the statement that they believe was not true of hers related to the narcotics story, Your Honor.
There was no evidence one way or another whether they believed the story with respect to the Attorney Malmgren.

However, they did -- the statement -- the prosecution did say, Let's not get that question out of this case so there'll be no question of prejudice, you know, to the defendant by the fact that his attorney made the some question of improper statements to a prosecution witness.
So that was how it all advanced and was either the last statement in the record on that Your Honor is that it either still pending or is been dismissed.
I assume it has been dismissed, but there has never been a hearing on it.
It has never been proved conclusively one way or another whether that allegation was correct or not.
Thank you, Your Honors.
Mr. Lassers.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
I believe that everything that we desire to say has been said, unless the Court has questions, I have nothing further.
Very well.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Can I ask you one last question?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Certainly.
In your petition for habeas corpus in the District Court, did you rely on the ground of coerced confession?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, Your Honor.
My recollection is that we did.
Yes, we did rely on that.
Well, did the District Court rule on it or not?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He ruled that it was not coerced, Mr. Justice White.
Did the Court of Appeals rule?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I think they did.
But at least you -- this is not the first time you've raised the issue of coerced confession in this Court, isn't it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In this Court?
You've raised it below, on the preserved two points of the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Oh, yes!
Very well.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
